utterance: Gin and gin-ger.
speaker: a stage-driver

utterance: Leave me go!
speaker: Flip

utterance: I ain't a bit frightened, I'm not going to run away, — don't you fear.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Glad to hear it, but why did you go for my revolver?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: I wanted to get hold of it before you did.
speaker: Flip

utterance: You did? - and why?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Oh, you know why.
speaker: Flip

utterance: I didn't know what you were hiding there for, and, I did n't see your face.
speaker: Flip

utterance: so you thought you'd freeze on to that six-shooter of mine until you saw my hand?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: I've seen six-shooters before now. Dad has one, and my brother had two derringers before he was half as big as me.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Perhaps you 'd like to take it now.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: What made you eat that grass, just now?
speaker: Flip

utterance: Grass!
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Yes, there.
speaker: Flip

utterance: I was hungry. Look! Do you think you could get me some breakfast for that, and have enough left to buy something for yourself?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: I reckon Dad might give ye suthing if he had a mind ter, though ez a rule he's down on tramps ever since they run off his chickens. Ye might try.
speaker: Flip

utterance: But I want you to try. You can bring it to me here.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: So you are hidin', are ye?
speaker: Flip

utterance: That's just it. Your head's level. I am.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Yur ain't one o' the McCarty gang-are ye?
speaker: Flip

utterance: Nor ye ain't one of them chicken lifters that raided Henderson's ranch? We don't go much on that kind o' cattle yer.
speaker: Flip

utterance: No.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Nor ye ain't that chap ez beat his wife unto death at Santa Clara ?
speaker: Flip

utterance: Well, then, I reckon you kin come along with me.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Where?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: To the ranch.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Then you won't bring me anything to eat here?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: What for? You kin get it down there.
speaker: Flip

utterance: I tell you it's all right. I'll make it all right with Dad.
speaker: Flip

utterance: But suppose I reckon I'd rather stay here.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Stay away then; only as Dad perempted this yer woods
speaker: Flip

utterance: Pre-empted.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Per-empted or pre-emp-ted, as you like,-ez he's got a holt on this yer woods, ye might ez well see him down thar ez here. For here he's like to come any minit. You can bet your life on that.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Come along, then; I'm your man.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Hand me your pistol first.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Looks kinder as if I was a prisner, don't it?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Go on, and don't fool.
speaker: Flip

utterance: This way.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Why do you have to go all the way round?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: We don't, there's a shorter cut.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Where?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: That's telling.
speaker: Flip

utterance: What's your name?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Flip.
speaker: Flip

utterance: What?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Flip.
speaker: Flip

utterance: I mean your first name, your front name.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Flip.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Flip! Oh, short for Felipa!
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: It ain't Flipper, — it's Flip.
speaker: Flip

utterance: You don't ask me mine?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Then you don't want to know?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Maybe Dad will. You can lie to him.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Only, you'd better agree with me.
speaker: Flip

utterance: What does your father do here?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Burns charcoal and makes diamonds.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Makes diamonds?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Many of 'em?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Lots. But they 're not big.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Oh, they 're not big?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Oh, Dad!
speaker: Flip

utterance: Flip.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Well! what's up now ? Yer ye are calling me from work an hour before noon. Dog my skin, ef I ever get fairly limbered up afore it's 'Dad!' and 'Oh, Dad ! '
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Ye'd better drop that axe and scoot round getten' this stranger some breakfast and some grub to take with him. He's one of them San Francisco sports out here trout fishing in the branch. He's got adrift from his party, has lost his rod and fixins, and had to camp out last night in the Gin and Ginger Woods.
speaker: Flip

utterance: That's just it; it's allers suthin like that. Why in blazes don't he g
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Why in thunder
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Now, look yer, Flip, it's playing it rather low down. on the old man, this yer running in o' tramps and desarted emigrants and cast-ashore sailors and forlorn widders and ravin' lunatics, on this yer ranch. I put it to you, Mister, I put it as a gen- tleman yourself, and a fair-minded sportin' man, if this is the square thing?
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: That's just it! D'ye reckon, be- ing a sportin' man and an A 1 feller, he's goin' to waltz down inter that hotel, rigged out ez he is? D'ye reckon he's goin' to let his partners get the laugh onter him? D' ye reckon he's goin' to show his head outer this yer ranch till he can do it square? Not much! Go 'long. Dad, you 're talking silly!
speaker: Flip

utterance: In course, you naturally ain't got any money. In course you In course you left your pocket- book, containing fifty dollars, under a stone, and can't find it. In course, you've only got a blank check on Wells, Fargo & Co. for a hundred dollars, and you'd like me to give you the differ- ence?
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: I want ter know how ye knew I was making diamonds
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Heard it in 'Frisco
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: I reckon they're gettin' sort of skeert down there them jewelers, yet it's in nater that their figgers will have to come down. It's only a question of the price of charcoal. I suppose they did n't tell you how I made the discovery?
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Certainly
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: It was cooled suddint, stunted by the water
speaker: Flip

utterance: That's it, that's just it. Thar's Flip, thar, knows it; she ain't no fool!
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: That's it, ye see. The carbon's just turning to di'mens. And stunted. And why? 'Cos the heat was n't kep up long enough. Mebbe yer think I stopped thar? That ain't me. Thar's a pit out yar in the woods ez hez been burning six months; it hain't, in course, got the ad- vantages o' the old one, for it 's nat'ral heat. But I'm keeping that heat up. I've got a hole where I kin watch it every four hours. When the time comes, I'm thar! Don't you see? That's me! that's David Fairley, that's the old man, you bet!
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: That's so. And now, Mr. Fairley, if you'll hand me over a coat or a jacket till I can get past these fogs on the Monterey road, I won't keep you from your diamond pit.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Ther's a deerskin jacket yer, that one o' them vaqueros left for the price of a bottle of whiskey.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: I reckon it would n't suit the stranger
speaker: Flip

utterance: If you're going to take the Monterey road, I can show you a short cut to it
speaker: Flip

utterance: That's it; let the chickens and the ranch go to thun- der, as long as there's a stranger to trapse round with; go on!
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: You know yourself, Dad, it's a blind trail, and as that 'ere con- stable that kem out here hunting French Pete, could n't find it, and had to go round by the cañon, like ez not the stranger would lose his way, and have to come back!
speaker: Flip

utterance: You did n't swallow all that rot about the diamond, did you?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: I don't know that it's any consarn o' yours what I think
speaker: Flip

utterance: And I suppose you've piloted round and dry-nussed every tramp and dead beat you 've met since you came here. How many have you helped over this road ?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: It's a year since there was a Chinaman chased by some Irishmen from the Crossing into the brush about yer, and he was too afeered to come out, and nigh most starved to death in thar. I had to drag him out and start him on the mountain, for you could n't get him back to the road. He was the last one but you.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Do you reckon it's the right thing for a girl like you to run about with trash of this kind, and mix herself up with all sorts of roughs and bad company?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Look! if you 're goin' to talk like Dad, I'll go back.
speaker: Flip

utterance: That is why, then, you take so much stock in tramps
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: You expect to recognize him?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Well, there is suthing in that, and there's suthing in this: some o' these chaps might run across brother and do him a good turn for the sake of me.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Like me, for instance?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Like you. You'd do him a good turn, would n't you?
speaker: Flip

utterance: You bet! only don't you go to throwing yourself round promiscu- ously.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: No, no one ever did. It shows, I had done 'em good, and they could get on alone. Don't it?
speaker: Flip

utterance: It does
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Have you any other friends that come?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Only the Postmaster at the Crossing.
speaker: Flip

utterance: The Postmaster ?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Yes: he's reckonin' to marry me next year, if I'm big enough.
speaker: Flip

utterance: And what do you reckon?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: That's telling.
speaker: Flip

utterance: ther 's your trail. It gets plainer and broader the further you get on, but you must use your eyes here, and get to know it well afore you get into the fog. Good-by.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Good-by.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: You 've got something for me
speaker: Flip

utterance: They 're paid for
speaker: Flip

utterance: That's so, but I thought ez it's a valooable package, maybe ye might want to examine it to see that it was all right afore ye receipted for it.
speaker: Kennedy

utterance: I'll risk it, and if it ain't right I'll let ye know.
speaker: Flip

utterance: We ain't had the pleas- ure of seeing you down at the Crossing for a month o' Sundays. Some folks let on you was keepin' company with some fel- ler like Bijah Brown, and you were getting a little too set up for the Crossing.
speaker: Kennedy

utterance: Then I allowed how ez you might have company, I reckon there's some city folks up at the sum- mit. I saw a mighty smart, fash'n'ble gal ca- vorting round. Hed no end o' style and fancy fixin's. That's my kind, I tell you. I just weaken on that sort o' gal
speaker: Kennedy

utterance: Strange I ain't got to see her yet
speaker: Flip

utterance: But you might get to see her at the edge of the Gin and Ginger Woods, if you'll take a pasear there with me.
speaker: Kennedy

utterance: Fine doin's this, yer receivin' clandecent bundles and letters, eh?
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: get on to the Crossing
speaker: Kennedy

utterance: Sit down, can't ye? Don't you see you 're a witness?
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Witness
speaker: Flip

utterance: Yes, a witness! He gave ye letters and bundles.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Were n't they directed to me?
speaker: Flip

utterance: in course, yes.
speaker: Kennedy

utterance: Do you lay claim to them?
speaker: Flip

utterance: No
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Do you?
speaker: Flip

utterance: No
speaker: Kennedy

utterance: Then, if you're not claimin' 'em for yourself, and you hear father say they ain't his, I reckon the less you have to say about 'em the better.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Thar's suthin' in that
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Then why don't she say who sent 'em, and what they are like, if there's nothin' in it?
speaker: Kennedy

utterance: Flip, why don't you?
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Maybe you forget how you used to row and tear round here because tramps and such like came to the ranch for suthin', and I gave it to 'em? Maybe you'll quit tearin' round and letting yourself be made a fool of now by that man, just because one of those tramps gets up and sends us some presents back in turn?
speaker: Flip

utterance: 'Twas n't me, Flip, 'Twas n't my doin'. I allus said if you cast your bread on the waters it would come back to you by return mail. The fact is, the Gov'ment is gettin' too high- handed! Some o' these bloated officials had better climb down before next leckshen.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: ye'd better find out whether one of those officials comes up to this yer ranch to steal away a gal about my own size, or to get points about diamond-making. I reckon he don't travel round to find out who writes all the letters that go through the Post Office.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Don't go out o' the way to ask the old man,
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: it's nat'ral a young gal should have her own advisers.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Unless ye're already in correspondence about more flour, ye might take the opinion o' the first tramp ye meet ez to whether Santa Cruz Mills is a good brand, but don't ask the old man.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: he was n't intrudin' on their secrets.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Suthin' I picked up at the Crossin' for ye to-day,
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: In course, when you've got your own flesh and blood with ye, ye can't go fool-in' around with strangers.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Clear out 'er that! Come, make tracks, will ye?
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Me heap sick,
speaker: an Indian squaw

utterance: I'll make ye a heap sicker if ye don't vamose the ranch,
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Me wantee Wangee girl. Wangee girl give me heap grub,
speaker: an Indian squaw

utterance: You bet your life
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Ye ain't brought no presents, hev ye?
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Ye ain't got no pooty things for poor Wangee girl?
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Me got heap cache nuts and berries,
speaker: an Indian squaw

utterance: Oh, in course! in course! That's just it,
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: you've got 'em cached only two mile from yer, and you'll go and get 'em for a half dollar, cash down.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Me bring Wangee girl to cache,
speaker: an Indian squaw

utterance: Honest Injin.
speaker: an Indian squaw

utterance: clear out all the tramps 'ceptin' yourself, and I'll keep ye in grub and rum.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: rum.
speaker: an Indian squaw

utterance: Now,
speaker: an Indian squaw

utterance: Se-crets again,
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: in course in course jiss so. Secrets that must be kep from the ole man. Dark doin's by one's own flesh and blood. Go on go on! Don't mind me.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Can't ye get the poor critter some whiskey?
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Ye used to be peart enuff before.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: It's like ez not,
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: that she'll be huntin' the woods off and on, and kinder looking after the last pit near the Madroños; ye'll give her grub and licker ez she likes. Well, d' ye hear, Flip? Are ye moonin' agin with yer secrets? What's gone with ye?
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: One o' the big pines above the Madroño pit has blown over into the run,
speaker: Flip

utterance: It's choked up the water, and it's risin' fast. Like ez not it's pourin' over into the pit by this time.
speaker: Flip

utterance: And why in blazes did n't you say so first?
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Ye did n't give me a chance,
speaker: Flip

utterance: Don't be alarmed,
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: it's only
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: What?
speaker: Flip

utterance: My coat and trousers.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: There's father.
speaker: Flip

utterance: But he's gone to clear away that tree?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Oh, I see,
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: That was a plan to get him away! Ah!
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Why did you come like that?
speaker: Flip

utterance: To see if you'd know me,
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: No,
speaker: Flip

utterance: It's to keep other people from knowing you. You 're hidin' agin.
speaker: Flip

utterance: I am,
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: but it's only the same old thing.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: But you wrote from Monterey that it was all over,
speaker: Flip

utterance: So it would have been,
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: but for some dog down here who is hunting up an old scent. I'll spot him yet, and
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: I couldn't wait any longer to see you, Flip, so I came here anyway,
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: I thought to hang round and get a chance to speak to you first, when I fell afoul of the old man. He did n't know me, and tumbled right in my little game. Why, do you believe he wants to hire me for my grub and liquor, to act as a sort of sentry over you and the ranch?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: I reckon as he 's that suspicious, I'd better play it out now as I've begun, only it's mighty hard I can't see you here before the fire in your fancy toggery, Flip, but must dodge in and out of the wet underbrush in these yer duds of yours that I picked up in the old place in the Gin and Ginger Woods.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Then you came here just to see me?
speaker: Flip

utterance: I did.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: For only that?
speaker: Flip

utterance: Only that.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Listen,
speaker: Flip

utterance: when Dad comes I'll get him to send you to watch the diamond pit. It is n't far; it's warm, and
speaker: Flip

utterance: What?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: I'll come, after a bit, and see you. Quit foolin' now. If you 'd only have come here like yourself-like-like-a white man.
speaker: Flip

utterance: The old man,
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: would have just passed me on to the summit. I could n't have played the lost fisherman on him at this time of year.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Ye could have been stopped at the Cross-ing by high water, you silly,
speaker: Flip

utterance: It was.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Yes, but I might have been tracked to this cabin. And look here, Flip,
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: I don't want you to lie any more for me. It ain't right.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: All right. Ye need n't go to the pit, then, and I won't come.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Flip!
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: And here's Dad coming. Quick!
speaker: Flip

utterance: He don't seem to be coming,
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: No,
speaker: Flip

utterance: I reckon I was mistaken. You 're sure,
speaker: Flip

utterance: you 're sure you 'd like me to come to you?
speaker: Flip

utterance: Sure, Flip?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: hush! he's coming this time, sure.
speaker: Flip

utterance: ye might rig yerself out in them new duds and fancy fixin's that that Sacramento shrimp sent ye, and let your own flesh and blood see ye. If that's too much to do for your old dad, ye might do it to please that digger squaw as a Christian act.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Ef you can't quit gigglin' and squirmin' like an Injin baby yourself, ye'd better git rid o' them duds,
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Ye see these yer fine dresses, ye might think is presents. Pr'aps Flip lets on they are? Pr'aps she don't know any better. But they ain't presents. They're only samples o' dressmaking and jewelry that a vain, con-ceited shrimp of a feller up in Sacramento sends down here to get customers for. In course I'm to pay for 'em. In course he reckons I'm to do it. In course I calkilate to do it; but he need n't try to play 'em off as presents. He talks suthin' o' coming down here, sportin' hisself off on Flip as a fancy buck! Not ez long ez the old man's here, you bet.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: That's why I want you to hang around her. Hang around her ontil my boy, — him that's comin' home on a visit, gets here, and I reckon he 'll clear out that yar Sacramento counter-jumper. Only let me get a sight o' him afore Flip does. Eh? D'ye hear? Dog my skin if I don't believe the d-d Injin's drunk.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Ye'll never be able to take yer watch at the diamond pit to-night, Dad,
speaker: Flip

utterance: and I've been reck'nin' you might set the squaw there instead. I can show her what to do.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Mebbee I've got suthin' else for her to do. Mebbee I may have my secrets, too- eh?
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: No, she 'll rest yer a bit just now. I'll set her to watchin' suthin' else, like as not, when I want her.
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: Dad,
speaker: Flip

utterance: there's torches movin' up toward the diamond pit. Likely it's tramps. I'll take the squaw and see.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Well,
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: what next?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: You're safe now anywhere outside the house. But did you expect them to-night?
speaker: Flip

utterance: Why not?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Hush!
speaker: Flip

utterance: they're coming this way.
speaker: Flip

utterance: Why, it's Kennedy and Bijah?
speaker: Flip

utterance: Who's Kennedy and Bijah?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Kennedy's the Postmaster and Bijah's the Butcher.
speaker: Flip

utterance: What do they want?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Me,
speaker: Flip

utterance: You?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Yes; let's run away.
speaker: Flip

utterance: The pit,
speaker: Flip

utterance: it's safe on the other side,
speaker: Flip

utterance: Flip.
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Well ?
speaker: Flip

utterance: What did the other two want? To see you, too?
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: Likely,
speaker: Flip

utterance:
"There's been a lot of stran-
gers yer, off and on.'
speaker: unspecified

utterance:
"Perhaps you'd like to go back and see
them?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Do you want me to?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance:
"Looks a little as if I
were running away, don't it?"
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance:
"No," they think you're only
a squaw; it's me they're after."
speaker: Flip

utterance:
"I reckon I'll
go back and see,"
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance:
"Go, tell Dad something's
gone wrong in the diamond pit, and say I'm
watching it for him here."
speaker: Flip

utterance: "And you ?"
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance:
"I'll go there and wait for him. If he
can't get rid of them, and they follow him
there, I'll come back here and meet you.
Anyhow, I'll manage to have Dad wait there
a spell."
speaker: Flip

utterance:
"Go in the back way, by the shed. Don't go
in the room, nor near the light, if you can.
Don't talk inside, but call or beckon to Dad.
Remember, you're
keeping watch of me for him. Pull your hair
down on your eyes so."
speaker: Flip

utterance:
"Do I know Lance Harriott? Do I know the d-d ruffian?
Did n't I hunt him a year ago into the brush
three miles from the Crossing? Didn't we lose
sight of him the very day he turned up yer at
this ranch, and got smuggled over into Mon-
terey ? Ain't it the same man as killed
Arkansaw Bob - Bob Ridley-the name he
went by in Sonora? And who was Bob Rid-
ley, eh? Who? Why, you d-d old fool,
it was Bob Fairley- YOUR SON!"
speaker: unspecified

utterance:
"What are ye talkin' about? I tell you I know. Look
at these pictures. I found 'em on his body.
Look at 'em. Pictures of you and your girl.
Pr'aps you'll deny them. Pr'aps you'll tell
me I lie when I tell you he told me he was your
son; told me how he ran away from you; how
you were livin' somewhere in the mountains
makin' gold, or suthin' else, outer charcoal.
He told me who he was as a secret. He
never let on he told it to any one else. And
when I found that the man who killed him,
Lance Harriott, had been hidin' here, had
been sendin' spies all around to find out all
about your son, had been foolin' you and try-
in' to ruin your gal as he had killed your boy,
I knew that he knew it too."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "LIAR!"
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance:
"Tell me, was Bob Ridley
your son?"
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: "My son," My son -is-is-is there!"
speaker: David Fairley

utterance:
"Hush! Didn't he tell you so?
Dead dead shot shot!"
speaker: David Fairley

utterance:
"Silence! are you crazy, man? that is not Bob Ridley,
but a dog, a coward, a liar gone to his reck-
oning. Hear me! If your son was Bob Rid-
ley, I swear to God I never knew it, now or
or-then. Do you hear me? Tell me! Do
you believe me? Speak! You shall speak."
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance:
"I say, old man, you
would n't mind giving me this, would you?"
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: "Thank you,"
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: "Good-by, old man,"
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance: "He's dead,"
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: "Yes,"
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance:
"You feel sorry for any one that's
dead, don't you?"
speaker: Lance Harriott

utterance:
"Lance, how long
you have been ! "
speaker: Flip

utterance:
"My boy-my son Robert —
came home came home at last - here with
Flip both of them come and see!"
speaker: David Fairley

utterance: "Suffocated!"
speaker: unspecified

utterance:
"Asleep! Asleep!
I've seen 'em lying that way when they were
babies together. Don't tell me! Don't say
I don't know my own flesh and blood! So!
so! So, my pretty ones!"
speaker: David Fairley

utterance:
"Good
night!"
speaker: David Fairley

utterance:
"Ye did n't none on ye happen to
drop anything round yer last night?"
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance:
"I dropped a pocketbook containing gov-
ernment bonds and some other securities, with
between fifty and sixty thousand dollars, but
no matter, if any man will return a few au-
tograph letters from foreign potentates that
happened to be in it, of no value to any-
body but the owner, he can keep the money.
Thar's nothin' mean about me,"
speaker: Peter Drummond

utterance: "But hev you?"
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance:
"I lost my pile to Jack Hamlin at draw-
poker, over at Wingdam last night, but I don't calkilate
to find it lying round loose."
speaker: unspecified

utterance:
"Ef I was you, I would n't flourish that yer ring around
much afore folks. I've seen better men nor
you strung up a tree by Vigilantés for having
even less than that in their possession."
speaker: Peter Drummond

utterance:
"And I would n't say much about bein' up
so d-d early this morning, it might look bad
before a jury."
speaker: unspecified

utterance:
"I'm dog-goned, ef I don't believe that Cass is looney over
that yer ring he found. Wears it on a string
under his shirt."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Oh, come here, please do; quick!"
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance:
"I heard some one coming through the
bushes, and I waited. Come
quick. It's something too awful for any-
thing."
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance:
"It was just here, just here that I went into the bush and cut
a switch for my mare, - and, just
here, look, see! this is what I found."
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: "But you 're not looking the right way; look there!"
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: "Ain't he horrid? but what killed him?"
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance:
"Turn him over again. May be you'll find another
wound."
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance:
"Perhaps you'd better ride on,
Miss, afore
you get summoned as a witness. I'll give
warning at Red Chief's Crossing, and send the
coroner down here."
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance:
"Let me go with you, it would be such fun. I don't mind being a
witness. Or, I'll wait here
till you come back."
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance:
"But you see, Miss, it would n't seem
right,"
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: "But I found him first,"
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: "Who is the coroner?"
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: "Joe Hornsby."
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance:
"The tall, lame man, who was half eaten
by a grizzly?"
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: "Yes."
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance:
"Well, look now! I'll ride on and bring
him back in half an hour. There!"
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: "But, Miss !"
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance:
"Oh, don't mind me. I never saw any-
thing of this kind before, and I want to see it
all."
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: "Do you know Hornsby?"
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: "No, but I'll bring him."
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance:
"Have you
been long in these parts, Miss?"
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: "About two weeks,"
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance:
"Good-by, just now. Look around for the
pistol or anything else you can find, although
I have been over the whole ground twice al-
ready."
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance:
"Here's something! It dropped from the
bosom of his shirt on the ground. Look!"
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: "Shall I open it?"
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: "Yes."
speaker: Joe Hornsby

utterance:
"It's a little ring, looks like
an engagement ring. Something is written
on it. Look! May to Cass.'"
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance:
"It's mine, mine! I dropped it. It's noth-
ing nothing,"
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance:
"a mere
trifle. I'll take it."
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: "Not much,"
speaker: Joe Hornsby

utterance: "But it's mine,"
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance:
"I found it six months ago
in the road. I picked it up."
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance:
"With your name already written on it!
How handy!"
speaker: Joe Hornsby

utterance:
"It's an old story. All Blazing Star knows
I found it."
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance:
"Then ye'll have no difficulty in provin'
it. Just now, how-
ever, we 've found it, and we propose to keep
it for the inquest."
speaker: Joe Hornsby

utterance: It was a fair fight, and was settled by the man az was peartest and liveliest with his weapon. We had a sort of unpleasantness over at Lagrange the night afore, along of our both hevin' a monotony of four aces. We had a clinch and a stamp around, and when we was separated it was only a question of shootin' on sight. He left Lagrange at sun up the next morning, and I struck across a bit o' buckeye and underbrush and came upon him, accidental like, on the Red Chief Road. I drawed when I sighted him, and called out. He slipped from his mare and covered himself with her flanks, reaching for his holster, but she rared and backed down on him across the road and into the grass, where I got in another shot and fetched him.
speaker: Kanaka Joe

utterance: And you stole his mare?
speaker: the Judge

utterance: I got away.
speaker: the gambler

utterance: I came here to refresh my memory, as Mr. Hornsby thought I might be asked to give my evidence again at Blazing Star.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: And you?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: I stumbled upon the place just now while prospecting, or I should n't be here.
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: Then it was you made these holes?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: No. Nobody but a stranger would go foolin' round such a spot.
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: I mean no one would dig here.
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: Do you mean to say that every miner does n't know that it's lucky to dig wherever human blood has been spilt?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: I never heard it before.
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: And you call yourself a California miner?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: I do.
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: You certainly do not seem like most of the miners I have met.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Nor you like any girl from the East I ever met.
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: What do you mean?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: What I say.
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: Did this ring belong to you?
speaker: the Judge

utterance: Tell us, Joe. Let it out and we'll make it easy for you.
speaker: a laughter-loving juror

utterance: Prisoner, remember that your life is in peril. Do you refuse?
speaker: the Judge

utterance: Well, as I reckon I'm not up yer for stealin a ring that another man lets on to have found, and as fur as I kin see, hez nothin' to do with the case, I do!
speaker: Kanaka Joe

utterance: Thank you, but I insist upon getting down.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: If the lady wants to ride inside, let her.
speaker: the driver

utterance: Just a minit, Miss, ye don't onderstand me. I only-
speaker: Joe Hornsby

utterance: Do you want this man inside?
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: No!
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Here! Somebody take my lines.
speaker: Mountain Charley

utterance: You're riding inside?
speaker: Mountain Charley

utterance: He is!
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: And you? onless you're kalkilatin' to take a little 'pasear' you're booked outside. Get up.
speaker: Mountain Charley

utterance: What a brute he was, ugh!
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Who? Oh, yes! I see!
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: I suppose I ought to thank you, but you know, really, I could have kept him out if you had n't pulled his wrist from outside. I'll show you. Look! Put your hand on the handle there! Now, I'll hold the lock inside firmly. You see, you can't turn the catch!
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: I hope you 're not flustered, Miss, by the- by the-
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: I?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Oh, dear, no!
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: One meets all sorts of folks traveling.
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: I dare say. I don't know. I never before met any one who was rude to me. I have traveled all over the country alone, and with all kinds of people ever since I was so high. I have always gone my own way, without hindrance or trouble. I always do. I don't see why I should n't. Perhaps other people may n't like it. I do. I like excitement. I like to see all that there is to see. Because I'm a girl I don't see why I cannot go out without a keeper, and why I cannot do what any man can do that is n't wrong, do you? Perhaps you do-perhaps you don't. Perhaps you like a girl to be always in the house dawdling or thumping a piano or reading novels. Perhaps you think I'm bold because I don't like it, and won't lie and say I do.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: You know you were shocked when I went to fetch that Hornsby, the coroner, after we found the dead body.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Hornsby was n't shocked.
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: What do you mean?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: You were good friends enough until -
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: Until he insulted me just now, is that it?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Until he thought, that because you were you know not so so-so careful as other girls, he could be a little freer.
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: And so, because I preferred to ride a mile with him to see something real that had happened, and tried to be useful instead of looking in shop windows in Main Street or promenading before the hotel -
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: And being ornamental.
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: Do you wish me to walk the rest of the way home?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: No.
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: Then stop that kind of talk, right there!
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: I wish I was a man.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: And yet I used to go to fires in Sacramento when I was only ten years old. I saw the theatre burnt down. Nobody found fault with me then.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Object? I'd like to see them do it.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: What's the matter with your neck?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Let me. Do! I'm good at wounds. Come over here. No-stay there. I'll come over to you.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: It's nothing.
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: Give me your flask.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: There. Now, button your coat over your chest, so, and don't take cold.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: What are you going to do with Hornsby?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: That will depend upon him.
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: Oh, you won't hear from him again, but you really ought to get up a little more muscle. You've no more than a girl.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: What shall I do with your handkerchief?
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: Oh, keep it, if you want to, only don't show it to everybody as you did that ring you found. Of course that was all nonsense. If you had cared so much for the ring you could n't have talked about it, or shown it. Could you?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: But did you really find it? Really, now?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: And there was no real May in the case?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: Not that I know of.
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: Perhaps you had better give me that handkerchief back.
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: No! no! Do you want to take your death of cold?
speaker: Miss Porter

utterance: You kin freeze to me, Miss.
speaker: Mountain Charley

utterance: I was told to give ye that by Miss Porter. Hush-listen! It's that rather old dog-goned ring o' yours that's bin in all the papers. She's bamboozled that sap-headed county judge, Boompointer, into givin' it to her. Take my advice and sling it away for some other feller to pick up and get looney over. That's all!
speaker: Mountain Charley

utterance: Did she say anything?
speaker: Henry Cass

utterance: Well, yes! I reckon. She asked me to stand betwixt Hornsby and you. So don't you tackle him, and I'll see he don't tackle you.
speaker: Mountain Charley
